title: What is the gdb command equivalent of bp MODULE_NAME+0x12345678 in WinDBG?
content:
What is the gdb command equivalent of bp MODULE_NAME+0x12345678 in WinDBG?

I found this command useful to debug with ASLR (w/o disabling it).

answers_data.content:
You can use gdb.Function from GDB's Python API to expose a function to your expressions to accomplish this. Essentially you'll be parsing the output of the info proc mappings command to get the base address you're interested in. I'm pretty sure that pwndbg does something like this, but if you prefer something lightweight the following in your .gdbinit might be enough. 

# define a function that is exposed as $baseaddy("module_name") in gdb.
python
import os
class baseaddy(gdb.Function):
    @classmethod
    def mappings(cls):
        mappings = gdb.execute('info proc mappings', False, True)
        rows = mappings.strip().split('
')

        # only grab rows that start with a number (ignoring headers)
        iterable = (index for index, row in enumerate(rows) if row.lstrip().startswith('0x'))
        index = next(iterable, 0)

        # extract the field names from the header
        headers = rows[:index][-1].rsplit(None, 4)
        iterable = itertools.chain(filter(None, headers[:1][0].rsplit('  ')), headers[1:])

        # join everything into a list of dicts
        fields = [header.strip() for header in iterable]
        return [{field : value for field, value in zip(fields, row.strip().split())} for row in rows[index:]]

    @classmethod
    def by_module(cls, module):
        # uses os.path.split to ignore the path and only match against the "module"
        objfiles, mappings = {}, cls.mappings()

        # create a dictionary of lists keyed by the "objfile" field.
        [objfiles.setdefault(item.get('objfile', ''), []).append(item) for index, item in enumerate(mappings) if int(item['Offset'], 16) == 0]

        # filter the dictionary for each "objfile" matching the "module"
        # parameter. we use os.path.split to strip out the path.
        iterable = (name for name in objfiles if os.path.split(name)[-1] == module)

        # get the list of matching candidates and select the "objfile"
        # and start address of each item. normally we would sort this to
        # get the minimum address, but we rely on our "objfiles" dict
        # preserving the order of the mappings we gathered.
        candidates = {(item.get('objfile', ''), int(item['Start Addr'], 16)) for item in itertools.chain(*(objfiles[name] for name in iterable))}
        if not candidates:
            # FIXME: need to return a failure or emptiness of some sort, but this is a function so..
            return gdb.Value(-1)
        if len(candidates) > 1:
            gdb.write("WARNING: More than one base address was found for module: {:s}
".format(module))
            [gdb.write("WARNING: Path at {:s} is mapped at {:#x}.
".format(fp, ea)) for fp, ea in sorted(candidates)]
            candidates = [next(iter(candidates))]

        # unpack the address and return it.
        [(_, ea)] = candidates
        return ea

    def invoke(self, parameter):
        return self.by_module(parameter.string())

# instantiate the class so gdb recognizes it
baseaddy=baseaddy('baseaddy')
end

(Apologies for the cut-and-paste job and haphazard documentation, this is just a snippet chopped out of my own .gdbinit at https://github.com/arizvisa/dotfiles/tree/master/posix/.gdbinit .)

The prior snippet literally parses the output of info proc mappings into a list of dictionaries that contain the fields for each item. Afterwards, it's used to filter the "objfile" field for each item, and then the minimum address of the filtered results are returned. Generally you should be fitting the boundaries of each mapping into an interval tree and updating it as new mappings enter and exit the process, but but as long as you're not repeatedly invoking this inside a breakpoint you'll probably be fine performance-wise.

Anyways, once you add that gdb.Function to your own .gdbinit file (and instantiate it), you can use it in your expressions as $baseaddy("bash") . The following could be an example of using it to set a breakpoint via break . 

(gdb) break *($baseaddy("bash")+0x20)
Breakpoint 4 at 0x555555554020
(gdb) p $baseaddy("bash")
$1 = 0x555555554000
(gdb) lm *bash*
0x555555554000..0x555555576000 (0x000000+0x22000)  /usr/bin/bash
0x555555576000..0x555555665000 (0x022000+0xef000)  /usr/bin/bash
0x555555665000..0x55555569a000 (0x111000+0x35000)  /usr/bin/bash
0x55555569a000..0x5555556a7000 (0x145000+0x0d000)  /usr/bin/bash

Reading through the man page shows the command break [file:][function|line]

More specifically you would load the file into gdb as normal, and then enter break function_name+offset_value such as: break main+12345678

comments.text: The main issue seems to be that the OP may not have an exact symbol name, though. So the question is about setting the bpx at the offset relative to the module's base address.
